content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 3 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would approach this game strategically to maximize my potential earnings over the three rounds. The payoff structure suggests that choosing R when my opponent chooses B could be disadvantageous, earning me 0$ while my opponent gets 35$. Similarly, if I choose B when my opponent picks R, I get 35$, but they earn 45$.

However, it's important to note that the game structure encourages cooperation since both choosing R in the same round results in a higher payoff (45$ each) compared to picking B (earning only 40$). Given this, my strategy would be to initially choose R as it offers a better outcome if my opponent also chooses R. If they reciprocate, we'll both earn more than if we had chosen B.

However, after the first round, I would consider adapting my strategy based on my opponent's choice in the previous rounds. If they choose R in the first round and I picked it too, I might decide to choose B in subsequent rounds to ensure that I get at least 40$ (the payoff for choosing B when both players pick B) and avoid the possibility of earning 0$ if we both choose R again.

If my opponent chose B in the first round, I would consider picking R in the following rounds since it offers a higher potential payoff if they change their strategy to R as well (45$ compared to 40$).

In summary, my initial choice would be R, but I would adapt my strategy based on the opponent's choices in subsequent rounds. My choice for the first round would be R ({R}).
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

In this case, since my opponent chose B in the first round and I chose R, I earned 0$ while they got 35$. This outcome indicates that my initial strategy may not have been optimal for maximizing earnings over multiple rounds.

For the next round, I would consider adapting my strategy to increase my potential earnings. Given that my opponent picked B in the first round, if I continue with R in this round, I will still earn 0$ as we both chose R. Instead, I would choose B for the second round since it offers a better payoff compared to choosing R (getting 40$ instead of 0$). If my opponent adapts their strategy and chooses R, I'll get 35$. However, if they continue picking B, we will both earn 40$ each.

In summary, for the second round, I would choose B ({B}).
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this case, since both of us chose B in the second round, we both earned 40$ each. This outcome indicates that our strategies may have converged to a mutual cooperation approach where choosing B offers a consistent payoff of 40$, which is still an improvement from the 0$ payoff for choosing R when my opponent chose B.

For the third and final round, I would consider maintaining the same strategy since we both seem to be cooperating by choosing B in subsequent rounds. By doing so, we will continue to earn 40$ each in this round as well.

In summary, for the third round, I would choose B ({B}).
